body:
It's a solid idea, but it's flawed because it still only represents 2 sides of the debate, just with a split between economic and social. Libright on the compass is more neoliberal than libertarian. And it can't seem to distinguish crony capitalism from free markets.

I think the triangle that compares the 3 different philosophies underlying most political beliefs is better: left (legislated equality), right (legislated hierarchy), and libertarian (less legislation, individualism). I actually made a quiz for that here: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle

It's still very early in development and in the making, so if you decide to take it let me know what you think.

---

This might actually also solve the argument about the existence of the libleft quadrant. I'd expect most libertarian-minded people to look at the auth/lib axis as more or less government involvement in people's lives, whereas others may see it as most test websites do as a conservative vs progressive thing. Under the former perspective, libleft indeed makes no sense: you can't have socialism without involvement from some kind of authority. However, with the latter way of looking at it, the government can still hold power, so libleft in that case is possible.
body_html:
It's a solid idea, but it's flawed because it still only represents 2 sides of the debate, just with a split between economic and social. Libright on the compass is more neoliberal than libertarian. And it can't seem to distinguish crony capitalism from free markets.

I think the triangle that compares the 3 different philosophies underlying most political beliefs is better: left (legislated equality), right (legislated hierarchy), and libertarian (less legislation, individualism). I actually made a quiz for that here: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle

It's still very early in development and in the making, so if you decide to take it let me know what you think.

This might actually also solve the argument about the existence of the libleft quadrant. I'd expect most libertarian-minded people to look at the auth/lib axis as more or less government involvement in people's lives, whereas others may see it as most test websites do as a conservative vs progressive thing. Under the former perspective, libleft indeed makes no sense: you can't have socialism without involvement from some kind of authority. However, with the latter way of looking at it, the government can still hold power, so libleft in that case is possible.

body:
thats actually right, if we could have a piramid with 3 axes, progressive, economic and freedom we would be able to understand better about pol, it would be a 3D example of things like:

>economy

more economy = market freedom
less economy = less freedom

>progressive

less culture = less progressivism
more culture = more progressism

>freedom


less freedom = less individual freedoms
more freedom = more individual freedoms

this alone would help us understand the vast majority of ideologies without the need to keep the label "left"and "right" because we would be able to properly place everything in their position

post.title: How yall are actually using the compass

body:
"Freedom to do whatever you like as long as it doesn't hurt anyone else" is still putting qualifiers on that freedom - what if I really, really want to kill everyone I don't like? Well, everyone else is free to kill you right back. Let's write that down so nobody can pretend they didn't understand the consequences of their actions. Who's going to keep the list updated? That guy seems to like doing that sort of thing and he seems to be reasonably competent at it, let's have him do it. Oh snap, now you've got a social contract, a legal system, and a government.

Everything past that is haggling over what that guy should and shouldn't be allowed to do. So far almost everyone agrees that he should manage the stuff that everyone needs but no one person wants to pay for, and that everyone needs to give him a bit of the money they make so he can pay for those things. That's about as far as we can get without getting into screaming matches. 

Well, I'm sure in a generation or two we'll have worked all the kinks out. It's not like things will keep being a mess until the gods kill us all out of frustration, right?

That guy seems to like doing that sort of thing and he seems to be reasonably competent at it, let's have him do it. Oh snap, now you've got a social contract, a legal system, and a government.

Everything past that is haggling over what that guy should and shouldn't be allowed to do. So far almost everyone agrees that he should manage the stuff that everyone needs but no one person wants to pay for, and that everyone needs to give him a bit of the money they make so he can pay for those things. That's about as far as we can get without getting into screaming matches.

Well, I'm sure in a generation or two we'll have worked all the kinks out. It's not like things will keep being a mess until the gods kill us all out of frustration, right?

body: Oh come on. Don't be ridiculous. Believing in freedom means believing in freedom for everybody, and that means you don't want to infringe on their rights either. You don't need a qualifier drawn in crayons. The restriction isn't a restriction on freedom at all, quite the opposite, it is a restriction on infringement, it is self evident and self explanatory.

post.title: How yall are actually using the compass

author.bio: Tell the Ruqqus community a bit about yourself.
author.bio_html: Tell the Ruqqus community a bit about yourself.

body:
I love what you're doing, but it may need some work.  With where it put me, I'm a super ancap.  In the real world, I know that ancap is a fantasy, much like the communist utopia.  I don't feel like I picked all of the ancap positions in the quiz, but I'll be honest I have no idea how to improve it to get what (I think?) Is a more accurate position in the chart for me.

https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/results.html?left=0&right=0&lib=8.33

If you want I can detail the answers I gave, don't know if you have some way to see them from the above (I doubt you can based solely on the url and args).  While developing this it may be beneficial to give each selection a number so you can get faster/easier feedback into how people answered to get their result?  Just a suggestion.

Keep up the good work, friend.  I wish I had the motivation to follow through on any of my personal project ideas.  I love where this is going, and I want to keep an eye on your progress.

Edit: maybe just putting the questions and your selected answers on the results page would be a better way to get that feedback?
body_html:

I don't feel like I picked all of the ancap positions in the quiz, but I'll be honest I have no idea how to improve it to get what (I think?) Is a more accurate position in the chart for me.

https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/results.html?left=0&right=0&lib=8.33

If you want I can detail the answers I gave, don't know if you have some way to see them from the above (I doubt you can based solely on the url and args). While developing this it may be beneficial to give each selection a number so you can get faster/easier feedback into how people answered to get their result? Just a suggestion.

Keep up the good work, friend. I wish I had the motivation to follow through on any of my personal project ideas. I love where this is going, and I want to keep an eye on your progress.

Edit: maybe just putting the questions and your selected answers on the results page would be a better way to get that feedback?

post.title: How yall are actually using the compass

author.bio: Tell the Ruqqus community a bit about yourself.
author.bio_html: Tell the Ruqqus community a bit about yourself.

body:
If number of questions remains short you could have an index for the answers and add entries to the query string for each.

You could also do what I see a lot of people doing and abuse local storage.  It makes things a nightmare to debug sometimes, though.

Yeah, minarchist is closer, I was more shocked at the visual of how close to ancap it placed me.  Maybe I really am that extreme and didn't realise it until now.  The traditional compass always placed me pretty close to center, leaning lib right, more lib than right I believe.
body_html:
If number of questions remains short you could have an index for the answers and add entries to the query string for each.

You could also do what I see a lot of people doing and abuse local storage. It makes things a nightmare to debug sometimes, though.

Yeah, minarchist is closer, I was more shocked at the visual of how close to ancap it placed me. Maybe I really am that extreme and didn't realise it until now. The traditional compass always placed me pretty close to center, leaning lib right, more lib than right I believe.

parent.body:
8.33 lib is not an ancap position, it's minarchist (which still supports the existence of a minimal state, not sure if that's closer to your view). Ancap would be a lib score of 10.

I'll consider adding what your answers were to the results page, although I'm not sure how I'd do it yet.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
So, it looks like you answered a libertarian opinion for every single question. Not the most extreme one every time, but you're definitely very libertarian-minded. Your ideology seems to be as little government and restrictions as you believe can still be sustainable. Sounds pretty minarchist to me.

Don't be shocked with how close you are to ancap. The primary disagreement between minarchists and ancaps is about whether it's possible to completely abolish the state without everything breaking down, and that's pretty much it. The underlying philosophy is the same, allowing as much individual freedom as possible. That's why the test placed you so deep into the libertarian section, and it makes sense; I'd say it's working as intended in this case.
body_html:
So, it looks like you answered a libertarian opinion for every single question. Not the most extreme one every time, but you're definitely very libertarian-minded. Your ideology seems to be as little government and restrictions as you believe can still be sustainable. Sounds pretty minarchist to me.

Don't be shocked with how close you are to ancap. The primary disagreement between minarchists and ancaps is about whether it's possible to completely abolish the state without everything breaking down, and that's pretty much it. The underlying philosophy is the same, allowing as much individual freedom as possible. That's why the test placed you so deep into the libertarian section, and it makes sense; I'd say it's working as intended in this case.
